title: City Data Pipeline – A report about experiences from using Open Data to gather indicators of city performance

author: Axel Polleres, Institute for Information Business, Vienna University of Economics and Business

segmentation: Thanks for the kind introduction and the opportunity to present here at the European Data Forum.
So I put here also my formal former affiliation, which was Siemens in Austria, also in Vienna.
So we've heard a lot of good things about Vienna today already, and I'll tell you a few more things which go on in Vienna from an industry perspective.
So I recently moved back to academia.
But what I want to present here is a use case.
On the one hand.
For how open data could help industry and also some challenges, which industrial use cases face when using open data?
So these use cases about an open city data pipeline or.
City data by plan for open data.
If you want to name it like that and comes from the following background, so in Siemens there's lots of studies being conducted about cities.
For instance, you see here a couple of title pages of such studies about different cities, or most prominently, which some of you might have heard about already.
the Europeans Green City Index, which is which is.
A study which compares European CVS in terms of sustainability aspects and define some KPI's for for measuring the sustainability and greenness of cities.

It is not so that is one thing which seems to us, but it's also obvious that an infrastructure provider like Siemens who sells infrastructure products like public transport facilities and energy grids etc is interested in such date about services.
Such assessments to make to make the best possible suggestions to series.
So what infrastructure they could need.
So that's why this data is interesting for infrastructure providers and what it needs is an up-to-date.
An up-to-date assessment of what what's going on in the city, right?

So how green is it is, for instance, and the goal of a pilot project we did there was to leverage open data for being able to conduct studies more dynamically because the problem problem is usually when you have such a paper study on PDF, it's usually outdated as soon as it's published already, which is quite natural in such a process.
So since open data is.
Changing a chance for getting at least the quantitative indicators for such studies more up-to-date and more quick.
That was one of the goals which we wanted to be able to do here.

So first of all, it was providing a pool of open data which would be relevant for subsidies, an integrated and 2nd to have flexible KPI model on top of that which could allow us to dynamically calculate such indicators.
OK, So what we see is the current status of open data, mean study.
Starting this pilot was basically yeah there is lots of different models for this pilot studies which we afford.
This KP eyes which we need to we need to implement and all this data is collected manually at the moment which is a very tedious process or it's even outsourced.
For example the Screen Safety Index was done in collaboration with the.
So with the Economist Business Intelligence unit.
And on the other hand, we see that much of this data is openly available already, which you need is input right?
For instance, UN data open data initiatives from various cities, or last but not least Euro stats.
And also it's forced by directives that parts of these indicators for countries at country or city level are being collected by directives from EU.
So there is already starting top down some harmonization on this, but not all this data is harmonized unfortunately so.
What you can imagine here would be 4 in there, for instance data.
So as I mentioned already, the Queen City Index, but also this most livable cities study where we saw already that we enter, was ranked quite high.

So in the Queen City Index setting DNS place #3 if I remember correctly amongst European cities and you have all kinds of data which you need there, like see you emissions per capita and traffic public public.
Transportation, network length etc.
Which go into these calculations so.
For instance, quite some of the indicators which we need there.
There are already European studies or centralized harmonized data is being collected.
One of one such examples is urban audit, which was started in the pilot study.
I think 1991 and collected this data every five years and it's also now being published for several CDs and collected as part of Euro stats.
So which collects already such data?
For instance, what you see here is.
If you can't read it doesn't matter, so it's just some of these indicators.
Like for example the the proportion of attorneys to work by public transport and all these indicators which are relevant to calculating such KPI's.
Of course based indicators like population Area, Green area etc are also important.
Other sources are.

Or heterogeneous so if you look for example, you could also gain such base data from Wikipedia or in a structured form already ready in linked data from DB pedia, where you get Bay State about the city like population and area and also some socioeconomic factors but also from the open city data.
Open open data initiatives from the cities like from Vienna you have lots of studies at a very detailed level, particularly also on a finer grain.
I'm level like on district level.
Like here the cars per person or what I mentioned already.
You could also collect and calculate some data from Key's data, for example from Street map would allow us to calculate the share of green spaces to some extent at least estimated for districts.
OK, so what's the aim of this study?
Boss of this pilot was to build a pilot which allows us to collect that data.
And periodically crawl the data from different sources which we integrate and also harmonize it so integrate different formats because we have lots of open data as CSV.
We have some open data as RDF we have, but we have also data which is just available as HTML tables which we have to extract and clean.
And then basically integrate this in the unified data.
Google for consolidation.
We use RDF there and graph database.
And then provide some statistical methods on top of that to aggregate that data.
And.
Then we would be able, hopefully to choose that such things like dynamically calculating the Screen, City Index, but even more being able to drill down and maybe calculate the Green City index for.
Ticular district or.
This case there is in Vienna, a city development project called Aspen Lakeside City.
In this 22nd District, which is a new kind of remote center being built there, which is a smart city project where we want to basically also be able to calculate indicators for this new.
This new district.
So what we've built here was a fairly standard pipeline for collecting the data, consisting of several wrappers for different data formats, which is configurable for various sources where we.
They see me automatically collect the data and integrated and then, so we store it.
Basically the key state that we started separating the keys database and the other indicators in an RDF store.

An integrated that in a very simple data model, so it's not a complex ontology we built here, but it's just really context that we group the indicators into various groups like demography, transport and traffic environment etc.

And then we have spatial context for these indicators which could be Country, City and district level and the temporal context from when these indicators are so when they were retrieved and for which the indicators are valid.
Obviously you can imagine already, but we not.
In all cases we can.
We have exact information from the validity, for instance from DB pedia.
We just have the retrieval time.
So we have to use you risztics to assume that this is the last value or when it was changed it was actually the actual value.
Goat.
So we use for these architectural extender technologies like Sparkling RDF to integrate that data.
And then we have implemented this using Rapidminer.
That's just the detail and using statistical components like.
Heart.
Um?
So at the moment, what so where we what we did in this study was integrating data mainly from European cities from 30 two different sources.
As I said already, we group these indicators into different groups like demography, geography, social aspects, an economy and environment.
This grouping was also inspired by the urban audit categorization already.
And we have collected data from 350.
So around 350 European cities.
So we focused at the moment on European cities because these were the main data sources we had available and also where we had the most open data activity, more or less.
And so you see some other things which have integrated here to your names, Euro stats.
And so we have not yet looked into a World Bank, but for instance, well, pink data is usually on country level, so we didn't get any city level data from there.
But we also drilled into some of the open data initiatives, for example to get data at district level level from Vienna, London and also partially from Berlin.
So we integrated this all in the interface, which would be usable for people conducting such studies where they could gather the indicators.
For instance, the population.
Exit from several sources.
So here you get just the information where this is coming from.
Because the provenance is important to see whether that's a reliable source and what are the different numbers and you see already that here we have the the indicator from different years.
So we say from when it isn't from which source?
So that's a very simple interface of course, but at least the main effort was in integrating all these indicators because they are slightly differently encoded or they are named differently.
At the difference.
OK, then you can also build some interfaces on top which resemble what you saw in the screen City an index.
So which allows us to compare certain cities per click and compare these indicators per cities in such a spider diagram for instance.
Now what applications can be further conceived on top of that except the studies?
Obviously what we want to do is we want to do this trend prediction.
For instance, if we want to.
Want to see how this new project will develop?
We want to have a guess based on the numbers which we have for plant people to be settled there and traffic situation there.
We want to have an idea of how things will be developing there for other social economic indicators.
And then let me talk about this first, maybe so.
The idea here was how can we estimate what will happen there?
And one thing which we did from the data which we got.
In the end we used some statistical methods to aggregate the data from the remaining districts of Vienna and we looked up on what was in the master plan for Aspen.
What would be the most similar district so it doesn't make sense to predict how this new central developed by the average data from the district it's located in?

Obviously because this is a very this is actually the most sparsely populated district of Vienna at the moment, and it has a different demography than the central districts, where is what we can expect is that the districts.
So what will happen?
This new smart city district will be much more similar than in the Central District.
So basically from the data we knew we clustered that with the other districts and try to see which district is most similar to Aspen and try to predict other indicators from that one.
Why is this important?
So it's also important if you want to, if you want to estimate these indicators for other cities, you could also compare and cluster similar cities, for instance.

What we obviously realized in our study was, for instance, that data from the Green City index for German cities was very homogeneous or much more homogeneous than four cities in the in the European Green City Index becausw.
These cities are often had a similar history, which also plays a role.
OK and have and have similar policies etc.
But we really wanted to estimate indicators just based on quantitative indicators available and that's where we use such clustering methods.
The idea is also that the more data we gather, the better such prediction methods methods will get.
Um, So what else we invest?

Located was how many of the quantitative data indicators which were used for the screen sit in the index could actually be gathered from open data and we got quite good coverage, so that's the positive messages that we could gather.
Lots of related indicators from open data and integrating them also from several sources.
But the problem is also what about data quality, right?
So we saw that some of the indicators were quite accurate from what we got from open data sources.
For instance, for population we had a.
Mean median error for only 2%, but for other sources we had completely different values which could serve different reasons.
For instance that in some data collections data is about the city area or something is about the Metropolitan area.
So you have to take care about how the data is collected and assessed before integrating it of course.
OK, so again the hope is the more data we gather and the more we analyze it for outliers instead etc.
The better we have prediction.
We can gain prediction models for having useful predictions from the data.
OK.
Let me close with challenges summarizing the challenges we experienced here.
I think some of them are mentioned already, but.
Let me stress again.
What is the use case here so we have heard we have heard a lot about open data being very valuable for new apps, new business models being developed for SMS.
For instance.
Most many of these new business models actually just use one data set or two 2 datasets or so so, but this use case.
What makes this use case specially is really that we want to integrate lots of datasets and particularly datasets from different countries.
And have them and integrate them in a compareable manner.
And that's I think why we ran into many of these challenges.
So for instance, one of the things is obviously incomplete data.
What you saw there for this?
For this indicator set for the Green City Index was only a small window of.
Basically the indicators we were collecting, but if you look at the overall set of indicators, there are many indicators which are just available for one city and not for the other.
So theoretically classic data mining methods are not really.
We work with this data set if you try to.
Also, because we don't have timelines available etc.
So to some extent, this incompleteness issues can be overcome using semantic technologies, which is also what many of the people here I saw are doing research in.
So you can use rules or some ontological inferencing to complete this data.
For instance, all in RDF, but also you need more, so you need more.
So link data and all is not enough.
You need for simple things like that.
So if I want to calculate the population density and I have population and area, I don't need the third indicator.
I can complete it, so I need to add like equation and knowledge.
There was one thing which we also built on top of that other things.
For completion Miss we what we tried to use was method methods which are particularly useful if you have lots of missing dots in such a. Matrix of data which were using matrix decomposition methods.
Unfortunately this also didn't work very reliably because that usually assumes that the data is normally distributed, which is not the case.

Another thing which is similar is basically that, for instance you have indicators which are just differently collected, like you have population total in PvP, then population sensors, which is usually almost the same but not quite etc.
So they're either in computer parable or differently named etc.
You have different indicators at different temporal and spatial granularity, so some of these if you have like all the data from all districts of a city, you can edit up.

Yes, you can just simply aggregate it, but you cannot always do this, and particularly if you want to drill down, you have to tailor your approximation methods to be able to soumen basically where you need this other things which I mentioned before, like taking the most probable measure for the drill down area.

OK, so another thing which is also very important when integrating this data, in particular when to when you want to apply open data in an industrial context is that the first question you get is probably what license does this data have and we see lots of different open data licenses which have all different conditions on how to use the data.
Like for instance we have Attribution licenses we have.
We have licenses which come without any strings, so you can use them just as is the data and.
So if you want to integrate data from different sources, what is the combined license for that data?
So we need standard behavior for that, either as in for example, the Austrian Open data portal it was done where it was decided to use one license, and other datasets which don't use their license.
Don't get into that portal, so that's fine.
But we need standards for also having integrated licenses.
The other thing.
At a very low level level of technical technical level is different formats for that data use, so I told her talked already about that.
Lots of data is available as CSV, separated values list.
Some is available as RDF, but it's not trivial to retrieve that data.

Even so, just for writing such a pipeline, it's not easy to write to collect the data in a machine processable manner, cause even if you use standard software for datasets, catalogs like seek, and if you look through these catalogs.
And try to download the CSV files.
You will have lots of different links etc.
And it's not trivial of whether you get from one link to a CSV file or to a web page which has links to the CSV file etc.
So I think we need to look more into more standard behavior of all these open data portals.
It's already brings me to the end of what I wanted to present for you.
The bottom line is, open data need stronger standards to be useful.

I think this was also something which was already mentioned in the morning by Mr Wrobel, who said that such standards and more high quality data sets are needed, and I think this is very essential for industrial uptake of open data, OK?
